odeComponent.htmlView:
1. HISTORICAL CONTEXT

The Baroque period lasted from 1600 to 1750 (approximately). During this time, absolute monarchies dominated Europe, and both the Church and the nobility used art to demonstrate their power and wealth. This era saw the flourishing of painting (Velázquez, Rubens), literature (Lope de Vega, Molière) and science (Galileo, Newton). The word baroque means overdone (recargado) or ornamented (adornado), and sums up the taste for excess and emotion. The Baroque mentality combines reason and feeling: it seeks technical perfection and, at the same time, to move the audience. 

To understand the change in mindset from the Renaissance to the Baroque, look at these two works of art:

  • Left: The School of Athens by Raphael -> A balanced and calm work, with clear lines, few shadows and a sense of harmony.

  • Right: The Elevation of the Cross by Peter Paul Rubens a dramatic work, full of contrast, movement and rich details.

odePagStructure.blockName: What does Baroque music sound like

odeComponent.htmlView:
2. CHARACTERISTICS OF BAROQUE MUSIC

2.1. Goodbye polyphony, hello homophony

During the Baroque period, music changed profoundly. Renaissance polyphony lost its dominant role. Composers abandoned its complexity and gave priority to a single main voice with accompaniment, a type of homophony: melody and accompaniment. This consists of a main melody accompanied by other instruments. In other words, we moved away from several independent voices singing different melodies to a main melodic line with accompaniment.

This change is very important, because most music today has a main melody with accompaniment


2.2. The basso continuo

Along with the concept of melody and accompaniment comes the idea of the basso continuo. This consists of a line of low notes that is maintained throughout the piece. It is played by instruments such as the organ, harpsichord or cello, and serves as a harmonic foundation.

2.3. Tonality (Key)

The concept of tonality became fully established: the rules of major and minor chords are established, and scales are consolidated as the basis of all Western music. We will learn about this in the section musical language. 

2.4. The measured rhythm

We abandon free time and move on to a measured rhythm, where the music acquires a regular pulse thanks to the use of bars.

2.5. Contrasts and virtuosity

Finally, Baroque music is full of contrasts: loud/soft, soloist/orchestra, low/high. These are essential for expressing emotions.

odePagStructure.blockName: Secular music grows, but religious music remains important.

odeComponent.htmlView:
3. VOCAL MUSIC

3.1. Opera

 

Opera originated in Italy in the early 17th century with composers such as Jacopo Peri and Claudio Monteverdi, author of Orfeo (1607), considered the first great opera. Opera combines music, theatre, poetry and dance; it is organised into arias, recitatives and choruses.

  • Arias: melodic and emotional solos for vocal display, with elaborate music and a pause in the action.
  • Recitatives: sung speech to advance the plot, with simple music and speech rhythm.
  • Choruses: pieces for groups that comment on the action or represent the crowd, adding texture and dramatic depth, unlike individual solos.

The three main genres are:

  • Opera seria: mythological and heroic themes. (We listen to: Julius Caesar in Egypt  by G. F. Handel | Aria: Se pietà di me non senti).
  • Opera bufa: Opera buffa: comical, everyday plots. (We listen to: La serva padrona by Pergolesi  | Aria de Serpina)
  • In Spain, zarzuela emerges, alternating between sung and spoken parts. (We listen to:  Celos aun del aire matan; (libretto by Pedro Calderón de la Barca and music by Juan Hidalgo de Polanco).

3.2. Religious music
Although secular music is gaining ground, the Church continues to play an important role. We highlight three types of pieces:

  • Oratorio: similar to opera, but with a religious theme and without staging. (Hallelujah!; Messiah, by Handel; chorus).
  • Cantata: a short work with religious text; J.S. Bach stands out (Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring de J.S. Bach).
  • Passion: recounts the death of Christ. (Pasión según San Mateo, by J.S. Bach; Overture).

odeComponent.htmlView:
4. INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC

4.1. Forms
In the Baroque period, instrumental music became independent from vocal music and the first purely instrumental forms appeared:

  • Sonata: a work in several movements for a few instruments. (Sonata for Violin in G minor: The Devil’s Trill by Giuseppe Tartini).
  • Suite: a succession of dances with different characters. (Suite for harpsichord in D minor. Fourth Movement:  Sarabande; by Handel).
  • Concerto: contrast between a soloist and the orchestra (The Four Seasons. Concerto No. 4 in F minor: L'inverno I. Allegro non molto by A. Vivaldi).

4.2. The orchestra

The orchestra is organised as a stable group of instruments, dominated by strings (violins, violas, cellos) and complemented by wind instruments and continuo. Instruments that were part of the orchestra:

String family: the violin became the central instrument of the Baroque period and the orchestra. Its expressiveness, agility and dynamics meant that many works were structured around it (such as Vivaldi's concertos). The Baroque violin, viola da gamba and cello were integrated into the orchestra as the main pillars of sound.


Plucked strings: harpsichord: essential for the basso continuo. It produces a clear, bright sound, although it does not change volume when the keys are pressed (unlike the piano). It is usually accompanied by a cello or viola da gamba to reinforce the bass line.

Woodwinds: flutes (traverso), oboe, bassoon. Wind instruments take centre stage. The traverso (baroque flute) and baroque oboe establish themselves as solo instruments in concertos and sonatas, bringing more varied colours to the orchestra.


Brass: trumpets and horns. Used mainly in ceremonial or court music to add brilliance and grandeur (for example, in fanfares or festive passages).


Percussion: the appearance of the timpani is noteworthy.

4.3. Virtuosity as an artistic ideal

As we have already seen, the Baroque period saw the emergence of the virtuoso performer, capable of executing brilliant technical passages and expressing dramatic contrasts with speed and precision. Virtuosos are performers capable of:

  • Playing fast, ornate phrases.
  • Mastering high and low registers with ease.
  • Improvising variations on a bass line or theme.

Virtuosity is particularly celebrated in concertos:

  • In a solo concerto, an instrumentalist stands out against the orchestra, as in Vivaldi's Winter
  • In the concerto grosso, a small group of soloists (concertino) dialogues with the orchestra (tutti). 

This role of the performer transforms Baroque music: it is not enough to play well, one must move the audience with technical precision and expressive contrast.

odeComponent.htmlView:
5. WOMEN IN THE BAROQUE PERIOD

During the Baroque period, despite enormous social difficulties and explicit opposition from institutions such as the Church, several female composers managed to make their mark and leave a real legacy in the history of music. The emergence of periodicals that spread sheet music throughout Europe allowed their work to circulate beyond their immediate surroundings. These women composed at a time marked by the Inquisition, devastating epidemics and prejudices as strong as the papal ban that claimed music was harmful to female modesty. Even so, they created music of enormous quality and participated actively in the cultural life of their time.

5.1. Who were they and what did they compose?

In Italy, Francesca Caccini worked at the court of Florence with the highest salary of all the ducal musicians and became the first known woman to write opera. Her Liberazione di Ruggiero 1625) was even performed outside Italy. In 17th-century Venice, Barbara Strozzi published her works without the support of powerful patrons, and her scores travelled throughout Europe; Rosanna Scalfi, for her part, wrote cantatas that were performed on gondolas during summer nights.

In France, Elisabeth Jacquet de La Guerre managed to gain a foothold in the court of Louis XIV and premiered the first French opera composed by a woman. Julie Pinel published a collection of highly acclaimed arias in a widely circulated music magazine.

In the Germanic territories, Wilhelmine von Bayreuth composed opera, chamber music and obras instrumentales during a period in which she also promoted the construction of the famous Margrave Opera House.

In England, Elisabeth Turner published canciones in the prestigious magazine The Lady and worked as a singer in various cities.

Contexto Histórico

El Barroco es el periodo comprendido entre 1600 y 1750, aproximadamente. Durante estos años, las monarquías absolutas dominan Europa, y tanto la Iglesia como la nobleza utilizan el arte para demostrar su poder y riqueza. En esta época florecen la pintura (Velázquez, Rubens), la literatura (Lope de Vega, Molière) y la ciencia (Galileo, Newton). La palabra barroco significa recargado o adornado, y resume el gusto por el exceso y la emoción.
La mentalidad barroca combina razón y sentimiento: se busca la perfección técnica y, al mismo tiempo, conmover al público.

A continuación podéis ver dos obras de arte:

  • Izquierda: La escuela de Atenas de Rafael Sanzio.
  • Derecha: La elevación de la cruz de P.P. Rubens.
